[[File:Leszek Kolakowski and Henri Lefebvre 1971.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Leszek Kolakowski]] and [[Henri Lefebvre]] in 1971]] The '''right to the city''' is an idea and a slogan that was first proposed by [[Henri Lefebvre]] in his 1968 book ''Le Droit à la ville'' <ref>{{Cite journal | last = Purcell | first = Mark | title = Excavating Lefebvre: The right to the city and its urban politics of the inhabitant | journal = [[GeoJournal]], special issue: Social Transformation, Citizenship, and the Right to the City | volume = 58 | issue = 2-3 | pages = 99–108 | publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] | doi = 10.1023/B:GEJO.0000010829.62237.8f | jstor = 41147756 | date = October 2002 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1023/B:GEJO.0000010829.62237.8f3 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://faculty.washington.edu/mpurcell/geojournal.pdf Pdf.]</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Unger | first = Knut | title = "Right to the City" as a response to the crisis: "Convergence" or divergence of urban social movements? | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120310001029/http://www.reclaiming-spaces.org/crisis/archives/266 | archive-date = 10 March 2012 | url = http://www.reclaiming-spaces.org/crisis/archives/266 | publisher = Reclaiming Spaces | date = 14 February 2009 }}</ref> and that has been reclaimed more recently by social movements, thinkers and several progressive local authorities alike as a call to action to reclaim the city as a co-created space—a place for life detached from the growing effects that [[commodification]] and [[capitalism]] has had over social interaction and the rise of [[Spatial inequality|spatial inequalities]] in worldwide cities throughout the last two centuries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://newleftreview.org/II/53/david-harvey-the-right-to-the-city|title=David Harvey: The Right to the City. New Left Review 53, September-October 2008.|website=newleftreview.org|language=en|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref> In his first inception of the concept, Lefevbre paid specific emphasis on the effects that capitalism had over “the city”, whereas urban life was downgraded into a commodity, social interaction became increasingly uprooted and urban space and governance were turned into exclusive goods.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://capitanswing.com/libros/el-derecho-a-la-ciudad/|title=El derecho a la ciudad {{!}} Capitán Swing|last=Swing|first=Capitán|website=capitanswing.com|language=es-ES|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref> In opposition to this trend, Lefevbre called to “''rescue the citizen as main element and protagonist of the city that he himself had built''” and to transform urban space into “''a meeting point for building collective life''”.<ref name=":0" />
Due to the inequalities produced by the rapid increase of world urban population in most regions of the world, the concept of the right to the city has been recalled on several occasions since the publication of Lefevbre’s book as a call to action by social movements and grassroots organizations. In their appeal for “their right to the city”, local mobilizations around the world usually refer to their struggle for social justice and a dignified access to urban life face to growing urban inequalities (especially in large metropolitan concepts). The right to the city has had a particular influence in [[Latin America]] and [[Europe]], where social movements have particularly appealed to the concept in their actions and promoted local instruments for advancing its concrete understanding in terms of policy-making at the local and even national level.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.uclg-cisdp.org/en/observatory/reports/competitive-metropolises-and-prospects-spatial-justice|title=Competitive Metropolises and the Prospects for Spatial Justice {{!}} CISDP|website=www.uclg-cisdp.org|language=en|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rioonwatch.org/?p=11668|title=What Is The Right to the City? {{!}} RioOnWatch|website=www.rioonwatch.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref> A good proof on how the notion of right to the city has gained international recognition in the last years could be seen in the [[United Nations]] [[Habitat III]] process, and how the [[New Urban Agenda]] (2016) recognized the concept as the vision of “cities for all”.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/oct/20/habitat-3-right-city-concrete-policies-ada-colau|title=After Habitat III: a stronger urban future must be based on the right to the city|last=Colau|first=Ada|date=2016-10-20|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref>
The growing popularity of the concept has nonetheless raised some criticism and concerns on how the original vision of Henri Lefevbre could be reduced to a “citizenship vision”, focused on the mere implementation of social and economic rights in the city leaving aside its transformatory nature and the concept of social conflict behind the original concept.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2018/03/16/seres_urbanos/1521194122_492095.html|title=Elogio y rescate de Henri Lefebvre|last=Delgado|first=Manuel|date=2018-03-19|work=El País|access-date=2018-06-14|language=es|issn=1134-6582}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{cite web | last1 = Gorgens | first1 = Tristan | last2 = van Donk | first2 = Mirjam | title = From basic needs towards socio-spatial transformation: coming to grips with the 'Right to the City' for the urban poor in South Africa | url = http://isandla.org.za/publications/152/ | website = isandla.org.za | publisher = The Isandla Institute | date = 2011 }} [http://isandla.org.za/download/assets/gorgens_and_van_donk_isandla_institute_acc-cubes_conference_paper.pdf Pdf.]</ref> [[Marcelo Lopes de Souza]] has for instance argued that as the right to the city has become "''fashionable these days''", "''the price of this has often been the trivialisation and corruption of Lefebvre's concept''"<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal | last = Lopes de Souza | first = Marcelo | title = Which right to which city? In defence of political-strategic clarity | journal = Interface | volume = 2 | issue = 1 | pages = 315–333 | publisher = via [[WordPress]] | date = May 2010 | url = http://www.interfacejournal.net/2010/05/interface-21-crises-social-movements-and-revolutionary-transformations/ | ref = harv | postscript = . }} [http://interfacejournal.nuim.ie/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/Interface-2-1-pp315-333-Souza.pdf Pdf.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119051241/http://interfacejournal.nuim.ie/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/Interface-2-1-pp315-333-Souza.pdf |date=2012-01-19 }}</ref> and called for fidelity to the original radical meaning of the idea.
==Overview== Lefebvre summarizes the idea as a "demand...[for] a transformed and renewed access to urban life".<ref>{{citation | last = Lefebvre | first = Henri | author-link = Henri Lefebvre | contribution = The right to the city | editor-last1 = Kofman | editor-first1 = Eleonore | editor-last2 = Lebas | editor-first2 = Elizabeth | title = Writings on cities | page = 158 | publisher = [[Wiley-Blackwell]] | location = Cambridge, Massachusetts | year = 1996 | isbn = 9780631191889 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last = Attoh | first = Kafui | title = What ''kind'' of right is the right to the city? | journal = [[Progress in Human Geography]] | volume = 35 | issue = 5 | pages = 669–685 | publisher = [[Sage Publications|Sage]] | doi = 10.1177/0309132510394706 | date = October 2011 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0309132510394706 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> [[David Harvey (geographer)|David Harvey]] described it as follows: {{quote|The right to the city is far more than the individual liberty to access urban resources: it is a right to change ourselves by changing the city. It is, moreover, a common rather than an individual right since this transformation inevitably depends upon the exercise of a collective power to reshape the processes of urbanization. The freedom to make and remake our cities and ourselves is, I want to argue, one of the most precious yet most neglected of our human rights.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Harvey | first = David | authorlink = David Harvey (geographer) | title = The right to the city | journal = [[New Left Review]] | volume = II | issue = 53 | pages = 23–40 | publisher = New Left Review | date = September–October 2008 | url = http://newleftreview.org/II/53/david-harvey-the-right-to-the-city | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>}}
A number of popular movements, such as the shack dwellers' movement [[Abahlali baseMjondolo]] in South Africa,<ref>{{cite web | last = Abahlali_3 | title = S’bu Zikode & Richard Pithouse debating Pallo Jordan on the Record of the ANC – Oslo, 22 November 2012 | url = http://abahlali.org/node/9405/ | website = abahlali.org | publisher = [[Abahlali baseMjondolo]] | date = 17 January 2013 }} (Campaigns and Statements on ''The Right to the City''.)</ref> the [[Right to the City Alliance]] in the United States,<ref>{{cite web | last1 = Leavitt | first1 = Jackie | last2 = Roshan Samara | first2 = Tony | last3 = Brady | first3 = Marnie | title = The Right to the City Alliance: time to democratize urban governance (blog) | url = http://www.plannersnetwork.org/publications/2009_fall/leavitt_samara_brady.html | publisher = Progressive Planning, Planners Network | date = Fall 2009 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100429105813/http://www.plannersnetwork.org/publications/2009_fall/leavitt_samara_brady.html | archivedate = 2010-04-29 | df = }}</ref> Recht auf Stadt,<ref>{{cite web | last = Staff writer | title = Congress theses on ''The Right to the City'' | url = http://wiki.rechtaufstadt.net/index.php/Congress_2011/Theses_to_the_Congress | website = wiki.rechtaufstadt.net | publisher = Recht Auf Stadt | date = 2011 }}</ref> a network of squatters, tenants and artists in [[Hamburg]], and various movements in Asia and Latin America,<ref>{{citation | last = Mayer | first = Margit | contribution = The "right to the city" in urban social movements | editor-last1 = Brenner | editor-first1 = Neil | editor-last2 = Marcuse | editor-first2 = Peter | editor-last3 = Mayer | editor-first3 = Margit | title = Cities for people not for profit: critical urban theory & the right to the city | pages = 63–85 | publisher = Routledge | location = New York | year = 2012 | isbn = 9780415601771 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> have incorporated the idea of the right to the city into their struggles.
In Brazil the 2001 [[City Statute]] wrote the Right to the City into federal law.<ref>{{cite web | last = Staff writer | title = Implementing the Right to the City in Brazil | url = http://sustainablecitiescollective.com/polis-blog/30417/implementing-right-city-brazil | website = sustainablecitiescollective.com | publisher = Sustainable Cities Collective | date = 14 October 2011 }}</ref>
More recently, scholars have proposed a 'Digital Right to the City',<ref>{{cite web | last = Joe Shaw and Mark Graham | title = Our Digital Rights to the City | url = http://meatspacepress.org/ | website = meatspacepress.org | publisher = Meatspace Press | date = 15 February 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Foth|first1=Marcus|last2=Brynskov|first2=Martin|last3=Ojala|first3=Timo|title=Citizen's Right to the Digital City: Urban Interfaces, Activism, and Placemaking|date=2015|publisher=Springer|location=Singapore|isbn=9789812879172|url=http://eprints.qut.edu.au/78107/}}</ref> which involves thinking about the city as not just bricks and mortar, but also digital code and information.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Shaw | first1 = Joe | last2 = Graham | first2 = Mark | title = An Informational Right to the City? Code, Content, Control, and the Urbanization of Information | journal = [[Antipode (journal)|Antipode]] | publisher = [[Wiley Publications]] | doi = 10.1111/anti.12312 | date = February 2017 | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/anti.12312/full | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>

{{Governance}}The concepts of '''security sector governance and reform''' ('''SSG/R''', or '''SSG''' and '''SSR''') generally refer to a process in [[Western world|Western]]-based [[international development]] and [[democratization]] to amend the [[national security|security sector]] of a state towards [[good governance]] and its principles, such as [[freedom of information]] and the [[rule of law]].{{Cite book|url=http://www.dcaf.ch/sites/default/files/publications/documents/DCAF_BG_1_Security_Sector_Governance_EN.pdf|title=Security Sector Governance: Applying the principles of good governance to the security sector|last=|first=|publisher=Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces (DCAF)|year=2015|isbn=|series=SSR Backgrounder Series|location=Geneva|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170915023424/http://www.dcaf.ch/sites/default/files/publications/documents/DCAF_BG_1_Security_Sector_Governance_EN.pdf|archivedate=2017-09-15|df=}}{{Cite book|title=Security System Reform and Governance|last=|first=|publisher=OECD DAC|year=2005|isbn=92-64-00786-5|series=DAC Guidelines and Reference Series|location=Paris|pages=}} The objective of security sector reform (SSR) is to achieve good security sector governance (SSG)—where security actors are effective and accountable to their people. For example, SSR might guide decision-making on what form should the oversight of armed forces take or how transparent will intelligence agencies be according to legislation.{{Cite book|url=https://www.un.org/en/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=S/RES/2151(2014)|title=UN Security Council Resolution 2151 (S/RES/2151) on Security sector reform: challenges and opportunities|last=|first=|publisher=United Nations|year=2014|isbn=|location=|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171121073122/http://www.un.org/en/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=S%2FRES%2F2151%282014%29|archivedate=2017-11-21|df=}} Different nomenclature of the same overall framework include '''security system reform''' ('''SSR'''), '''security sector reconstruction''' ('''SSR''') and '''justice and security sector reform''' ('''JSSR''').{{Cite book|url=http://www.dcaf.ch/sites/default/files/publications/documents/DCAF_BG_2_Security%20Sector%20Reform.pdf|title=Security Sector Reform: Applying the principles of good governance to the security sector|last=|first=|publisher=DCAF|year=2015|isbn=|series=SSR Backgrounder Series|location=Geneva|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170913183845/http://www.dcaf.ch/sites/default/files/publications/documents/DCAF_BG_2_Security%20Sector%20Reform.pdf|archivedate=2017-09-13|df=}} == History == In 1994, the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]] (OSCE) adopted a Code of Conduct on Politico-Military Aspects of Security stating that the democratic control of the security sector as essential to stability.{{Cite book|url=http://www.osce.org/fsc/41355?download=true|title=Code of Conduct on Politico-Military Aspects of Security|last=|first=|publisher=OSCE|year=1994|isbn=|location=Vienna|pages=3|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829145812/http://www.osce.org/fsc/41355?download=true|archivedate=2017-08-29|df=}} A framework for security sector reform (SSR) emerged in 1999 after [[international development]] actors observed from examples in [[South Africa]], [[Indonesia]] and countries in Eastern Europe that national security and its components were considered crucial in a state recovering from [[War|conflict]] or an [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian regime]]. Reportedly, the increasing number of [[Civil war|civil wars]] led development actors to look at the problem of insecurity from the perspective of good governance. The conclusion was that the security sector should adhere to the same rules of good governance as any other public service to curb conflict and violence.{{Cite news|url=https://www.clingendael.nl/publication/ssr-securing-its-success-justifying-its-relevance|title=SSR: Securing its success, justifying its relevance|last=Price|first=Megan|date=2014-08-19|work=Clingendael|access-date=|last2=van Veen|first2=Erwin|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170826234737/https://www.clingendael.nl/publication/ssr-securing-its-success-justifying-its-relevance|archivedate=2017-08-26|df=}} In 2014, the [[United Nations Security Council]] (UNSC) adopted its first stand-alone resolution on SSR and within it the role of security sector reform in stabilizing post-conflict countries.{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/press/en/2014/sc11369.doc.htm|title=Unanimously Adopting Resolution 2151 (2014), Security Council Underscores Need for National Ownership of Security-Sector Reform|last=|first=|date=2014-04-28|website=www.un.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-25|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820151018/http://www.un.org/press/en/2014/sc11369.doc.htm|archivedate=2017-08-20|df=}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/presscenter/articles/2015/02/13/undp-sees-security-sector-reform-as-foundation-for-peace-and-development-.html|title=UNDP sees Security Sector Reform as foundation for Peace and Development|last=|first=|date=2015-02-13|website=UNDP|language=en|access-date=2017-08-25|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170826000511/http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/presscenter/articles/2015/02/13/undp-sees-security-sector-reform-as-foundation-for-peace-and-development-.html|archivedate=2017-08-26|df=}} == Scope == [[File:Female police officer of Denmark.jpg|thumb|The [[Service quality|quality of the service]] provided by the police, such as the pictured [[Police of Denmark]], is a component of security sector governance and reform]]There is no single globally accepted definition of security sector reform (SSR), but it generally refers to a process to reform or rebuild a state's [[National security|security sector]] towards good security sector governance (SSG).{{Cite book|url=https://ec.europa.eu/europeaid/sites/devco/files/joint-communication-ssr-20160705-p1-854572_en.pdf|title=Elements for an EU-wide strategic framework to support security sector reform, JOIN(2016) 31 final|last=|first=|publisher=European Commission|year=2016|isbn=|location=Strasbourg|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170825234526/https://ec.europa.eu/europeaid/sites/devco/files/joint-communication-ssr-20160705-p1-854572_en.pdf|archivedate=2017-08-25|df=}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/115810.pdf|title=Security Sector Reform|last=|first=|publisher=USAID, US Departments of Defense and State|year=2009|isbn=|location=|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107024030/https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/115810.pdf|archivedate=2017-11-07|df=}} Good SSG is usually defined as a number of idealized principles and good practices of a healthy security sector servicing its people. Likewise, the objective of SSR is defined as the application of the same principles of [[good governance]] to the security sector as to any other public sector service delivery, such as [[public health]] or [[education]].{{Cite web|url=http://dcaf.ch/about-ssgr|title=About SSG/R|last=|first=|date=|website=DCAF (Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces)|language=en|access-date=2017-11-04|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107012716/http://dcaf.ch/about-ssgr|archivedate=2017-11-07|df=}} For example, the [[Development Assistance Committee]] (DAC) of the [[OECD|Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (]]OECD) has defined four standards that SSR should strive for:
1. Establishment of effective governance, oversight and accountability in the security system; 2) improved delivery of security and justice services; 3) development of local leadership and ownership of the reform process; and 4) sustainability of justice and security service delivery.
The target of SSR are the components of the state that uphold [[national security]]. Although the security sector is therefore a wide term open to interpretation, it is generally used to describe the structures, institutions and personnel responsible for the management, provision and oversight of security in a certain country.{{Cite book|url=https://www.un.org/en/peacekeeping/publications/ssr/ssr_perspective_2012.pdf|title=The United Nations SSR Perspective|last=|first=|publisher=UN SSR Unit|year=2012|isbn=|location=New York|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519215426/http://www.un.org/en/peacekeeping/publications/ssr/ssr_perspective_2012.pdf|archivedate=2017-05-19|df=}} Therefore, the scope and target of SSR has usually been defined comprising the following four groups: * Core security actors, such as armed forces, police, gendarmerie, border guards, customs and immigration, and intelligence and security services; * security management and oversight bodies, such as ministries of defence and internal affairs, financial management bodies and public complaints commissions; * justice and law enforcement institutions, such as the judiciary, prisons, prosecution services, traditional justice systems; and * non-statutory security forces, such as private security companies, guerrilla armies and private militia.{{Cite book|url=https://www.eda.admin.ch/content/dam/deza/en/documents/themen/fragile-kontexte/224402-oecd-handbook-security-system-reform_EN.pdf|title=The OECD DAC Handbook on Security System Reform (SSR) - Supporting Security and Justice|last=|first=|publisher=OECD DAC|year=2007|isbn=|location=Paris|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170821172956/https://www.eda.admin.ch/content/dam/deza/en/documents/themen/fragile-kontexte/224402-oecd-handbook-security-system-reform_EN.pdf|archivedate=2017-08-21|df=}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.unog.ch/80256EDD006B8954/%28httpAssets%29/904B9EE812B7591FC12573F400322816/$file/Joint+Seminar_A-62-659_S-2008-39.pdf|title=Securing peace and development: the role of the United Nations in supporting security sector reform - Report of the Secretary-General (A/62/659)|last=|first=|publisher=United Nations|year=2008|isbn=|location=New York|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140905032133/http://www.unog.ch/80256EDD006B8954/(httpAssets)/904B9EE812B7591FC12573F400322816/$file/Joint+Seminar_A-62-659_S-2008-39.pdf|archivedate=2014-09-05|df=}}{{Cite news|url=https://fba.se/en/how-we-work/security-sector-reform/|title=Security Sector Reform|last=|first=|date=|work=Folke Bernadotte Academy|access-date=2017-08-23|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160826130304/https://fba.se/en/how-we-work/security-sector-reform/|archivedate=2016-08-26|df=}} == Objective == [[File:SSG and SSR.png|thumb|A diagram of the relationship between security sector reform and governance relative to time and quality|left]]To observe and measure the quality of SSG as well as set more definite objectives, [[international development]] actors generally break down good security sector governance into different principless that are believed to showcase different subparts of a healthy security sector under democratic control.{{Cite web|url=http://www.unescap.org/resources/what-good-governance|title=What is Good Governance?|last=|first=|date=2009-06-10|website=United Nations ESCAP|language=en|access-date=2017-04-09|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170423153306/http://www.unescap.org/resources/what-good-governance|archivedate=2017-04-23|df=}} While exact configurations vary, some of the most common principles or objectives of good SSG that are commonly used include [[accountability]], [[rule of law]], and [[effectiveness]].{{Cite book|url=http://www.osce.org/secretariat/231176|title=Security Sector Governance and Reform: Guidelines for OSCE Staff|last=|first=|publisher=Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE)|year=2016|isbn=|location=Vienna|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170825185357/http://www.osce.org/secretariat/231176|archivedate=2017-08-25|df=}}{{Cite journal|last=Weiss|first=Thomas G.|date=2000-10-01|title=Governance, good governance and global governance: Conceptual and actual challenges|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/713701075|journal=Third World Quarterly|volume=21|issue=5|pages=795–814|doi=10.1080/713701075|issn=0143-6597}} A multitude of different practical situations of good SSG exist according to development actors: For example, in a security sector lead by good governance, the [[use of force]] is defined by a legal framework. This subsequently requires, among others, that publicly transparent [[law]]s are in place; oversight and [[separation of powers]] mechanisms are established and working; and the state's [[Legitimacy (political)|legitimate]] use of force is regulated through strategies and policies. An operational level example would be improved and open interaction between the public and the security sector, including functioning [[freedom of information]] and [[complaint]] institutes. SSR is aimed at the existence of both national security and [[human security]]. However, the goals of providing national and human security can be conflictual in the context of conflict-torn societies which lack the framework of democratic governance. According to Florian Weigand, the experiences of SSR in [[Afghanistan]], for example, have prompted a debate on the advantages of providing human rather than state security in the process of state-building.{{Cite book|url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/internationalDevelopment/pdf/WP/WP135.pdf|title=How can security sector reforms contribute to State-Building? The case of the Afghan Police Reform|last=Weigand|first=Florian|publisher=London School of Economics and Political Science|year=2013|isbn=|location=London|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809085941/http://www.lse.ac.uk/internationaldevelopment/pdf/wp/wp135.pdf|archivedate=2017-08-09|df=}} ==Implementation== [[File:MONUSCO SSR.jpg|thumb|The [[United Nations|UN]] peacekeeping operation in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] ([[MONUSCO]]) providing security sector reform assistance]]SSR is considered an instrument of international [[development aid]]; and attaining good SSG is seen by practitioners as a conflict prevention tool and as a post-conflict stabilizer.{{Cite web|url=http://www.isf2016.ch/Programme/Summaries/1.3.-Security-Sector-Governance-in-West-Africa-Regional-norms-Local-experiences|title=Security Sector Governance in West Africa: Regional norms, local experiences|last=International Security Forum 2016|first=|date=2016-06-13|website=www.isf2016.ch|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-05-29|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170825190641/http://www.isf2016.ch/Programme/Summaries/1.3.-Security-Sector-Governance-in-West-Africa-Regional-norms-Local-experiences|archivedate=2017-08-25|df=}} Examples of mechanisms that international actors reportedly use to perform security sector reform include [[disarmament, demobilization and reintegration]] (DDR) programmes to try and synchronize reforms to the security sector—and rule of law reforms as justice and security sectors are often considered intertwined.{{Cite book|url=http://www.unddr.org/uploads/documents/IDDRS%206.10%20DDR%20and%20SSR.pdf|title=Integrated Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration Standards|last=|first=|publisher=UN DDR Resource Centre|year=2009|isbn=|location=|pages=|chapter=6.10 DDR and Security Sector Reform|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151123003322/http://www.unddr.org/uploads/documents/IDDRS%206.10%20DDR%20and%20SSR.pdf|archivedate=2015-11-23|df=}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.ictj.org/sites/default/files/ICTJ-DDR-SSR-ResearchBrief-2010-English.pdf|title=Transitional Justice, DDR, and Security Sector Reform|last=Cutter Patel|first=Ana|publisher=International Center for Transitional Justice|year=2010|isbn=|location=|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107002910/https://www.ictj.org/sites/default/files/ICTJ-DDR-SSR-ResearchBrief-2010-English.pdf|archivedate=2017-11-07|df=}} Likewise, SSR can be performed along transitional justice processes if the security sector has a legacy of violence against the population—and during [[security policy]] discussions to use SSR in supporting the implementation and reviews of the states' national security policy and strategy. SSR is not understood by researchers to be limited to a single political situation, but rather can be introduced in various contexts. The circumstances under which reform efforts are undertaken are often classified as three different reform environments: post-conflict, [[Provisional government|transitional]] and [[Developed country|developed countries]]. Nevertheless, security sector reform is most commonly introduced in post-conflict settings after [[war]] has ceased.{{Cite book|url=http://www.dcaf.ch/security-governance-post-conflict-peacebuilding|title=Security Governance in Post-Conflict Peacebuilding|last=Bryden|first=Alan|last2=Hänggi|first2=Heiner|publisher=Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces (DCAF)|year=2005|isbn=978-3-8258-9019-3|location=Geneva|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170915024200/http://www.dcaf.ch/security-governance-post-conflict-peacebuilding|archivedate=2017-09-15|df=}} However, its insensitive application to such contexts has raised criticism. For example, Jane Chanaa has argued that there is a concept–context divide because conceptualisation overshadowed the understanding on how the idea adapts to the local situations whereas Safal Ghimire has noted that such a chasm exists also because the 'SSR' concept does not talk about reforms in the benefactors.{{Cite book|title=Chanaa, Jane. {{Companies law}} A '''sole proprietorship''', also known as the '''sole trader''', '''individual entrepreneurship''' or '''proprietorship''', is a type of enterprise that is owned and run by one person and in which there is no legal distinction between the owner and the [[Types of business entity|business entity]]. The owner is in direct control of all elements and is legally accountable for the finances of such business and this may include debts, loans, loss, etc. A sole trader does not necessarily work 'alone'—it is possible for the sole trader to employ other people.<ref>The Accountancy Partnership, [https://www.theaccountancy.co.uk/articles/information/can-a-sole-trader-have-employees-639.html Can a sole trader have employees?] published 10 March 2012, accessed 22 September 2018</ref>
The sole trader receives all profits (subject to taxation specific to the business) and has unlimited responsibility for all losses and debts. Every asset of the business is owned by the proprietor and all debts of the business are the proprietor's. It is a "sole" proprietorship in contrast with [[partnership]]s (which have at least two owners).
A sole proprietor may use a [[trade name]] or business name other than their or its legal name. They may have to legally trademark their business name if it differs from their own legal name, the process varying depending upon country of residence.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.smallbusiness.wa.gov.au/step-3-how-do-i-register-my-business-name/|title = Small Business.gov.au - How do I register my business name?|date = |accessdate = 2015-07-13|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140820064531/http://www.smallbusiness.wa.gov.au/step-3-how-do-i-register-my-business-name/|archive-date = 2014-10-18|dead-url = yes|df = }}</ref>
==Advantages and disadvantages== Registration of a business name for a sole proprietor is generally uncomplicated unless it involves the selection of a name that is fictitious, or “assumed”. The business owner is required to register with the appropriate [[local authorities]], who will determine that the name submitted is not duplicated by another [[business entity]]. Furthermore, the business owner must complete a form submitted to the governing authority to acquire title as a “DBA” or "[[doing business as]]”. The authority in some US states is the Secretary of State.
The license for a sole proprietary business entitles the owner to hire [[Employment|employees]] and enlist the services of [[Independent contractor|independent consultants]]. Although an employee or consultant may be requested by the owner to complete a specific project or participate in the company's [[decision-making]] process, their contribution to the project or decision is considered a ''recommendation'' under the law. Under the [[legal doctrine]] ''Respondeat superior'' ([[Latin]]: "let the master answer"), the [[legal liability]] for any business decision arising from such a contribution remains upon the owner and cannot be renounced or [[Apportionment|apportioned]].
This is transposed by the unlimited liability attached to a sole proprietary business. The owner carries the financial responsibility for all [[debts]] and/or losses suffered by the business, to the extent of using personal or other assets, to discharge any outstanding [[Liability (financial accounting)|liabilities]]. The owner is exclusively liable for all business activities conducted by the sole proprietorship and accordingly, entitled to full control and all earnings associated with it. The general aspect according to the general business law is that this type of business owner does not embody a “[[legal entity]]” Furthermore, any attempted and unreliable distinctions of the business do not change the classification under this title.
==Rules for sole proprietorships in different countries==
===Ireland=== In [[Ireland]], a sole trader who wishes to use a business name must register that name with the [[Companies Registration Office (Ireland)|Companies Registration Office]] (CRO).<ref>Citizens Information Board, [http://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/employment/types_of_employment/self_employment/setting_up_a_business_in_ireland.html Starting a Business], published 21 March 2018, accessed 22 September 2018</ref>
=== Malaysia === ==== Registration of Sole Proprietorships ==== In [[Malaysia]], there are three different laws governing the registration and administration of sole proprietors:- # West Malaysia and the Federal Territory of [[Labuan]]: Registration of Business Act 1956 (Act 197);<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ssm.com.my/sites/default/files/acts/fscommand/a0197.htm|title=Registration of Business Act 1956|last=|first=|date=|website=Companies Commission of Malaysia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-01-16}}</ref> # [[Sarawak]]: Businesses, Professions and Trade Licensing Ordinance [Sarawak Chapter 33];<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.betong.sarawak.gov.my/modules/web/pages.php?mod=publication&sub=publication_show&id=9|title=Business, Profession and Trade Licensing Ordinance (Sarawak Chapter 33)|last=|first=|date=|website=Betong Division Website|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 January 2018}}</ref> & Business Names Ordinance for the State of Sarawak [Sarawak Chapter 64]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.betong.sarawak.gov.my/modules/web/pages.php?mod=publication&sub=publication_show&id=8|title=Sarawak Business Names Ordinance|last=|first=|date=|website=Betong Division Website|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 January 2018}}</ref> and # [[Sabah]]: Trades Licensing Ordinance for the State of Sabah [Sabah Chapter 144].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lawnet.sabah.gov.my/Lawnet/SabahLawsDeclaredFederal/TradesLicensingOrdinance(SabahCap144).pdf|title=Trades Licensing Ordinance [Sabah Chapter 144]|last=|first=|date=|website=Sabah State Attorney-General's Chambers|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In West Malaysia, the registration of sole proprietors come under the purview of the [[Companies Commission of Malaysia]] (''Suruhanjaya Syarikat Malaysia'', or abbreviated as ''SSM''). In Sabah and Sarawak (with the exception of Kuching), the registration of businesses are done at the local authorities (e.g. municipal councils or district offices) while in [[Kuching]], sole proprietors are registered with the Kuching Office of the Malaysian Inland Revenue Board.
Sole proprietors, which includes the self-employed, must register with the relevant authority within thirty (30) days from the commencement of their business<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ssm.com.my/sites/default/files/guidelines/OWNER%20RESPONSIBILITY_new.pdf|title=Responsibility of Business Owner|last=|first=|date=|website=Companies Commission of Malaysia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 January 2018}}</ref>. Sole proprietors may register their business using one of two names: (1) their legal name following the registrant's identity card or (2) a trade name<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ssm.com.my/en/sole/starting-a-sole-proprietorship-partnership|title=Starting a Sole Proprietorship/Partnership|last=|first=|date=|website=Companies Commission of Malaysia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 January 2018}}</ref>. Registration of a business lasts either one or two years, and must be renewed thirty (30) days before its expiry<ref name=":0" />.
In the event of termination of business, the proprietor has thirty (30) days from the termination date to file the notice with the relevant authority<ref name=":0" />. If the termination is caused by the death of the proprietor, the administrators of the estate has four (4) months from the death date to file a notice of termination<ref name=":0" />.
==== Goods and Services Tax (GST) ==== Sole proprietors must register with the Royal Malaysian Customs Department to charge and collect goods and services tax (GST) once their taxable turnover within a 12 month-period exceeds RM500,000<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gst.customs.gov.my/en/SiteAssets/doc/Registering%20for%20GST%20Amend%201.pdf|title=Getting Ready for GST – Registering for GST|last=|first=|date=|website=Royal Malaysian Customs Department|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 January 2018}}</ref>.
==== Sole Proprietors as Employers ==== Similar to other Common Law jurisdiction, proprietors may enter into contracts of employment and/or apprenticeship with their employees. Sole proprietors, as employers, are responsible to:- * Make contribution to their employees' Employees Provident Fund<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kwsp.gov.my/portal/en/employers|title=EPF - Employers - KWSP|website=www.kwsp.gov.my|language=ms-MY|access-date=2018-01-16}}</ref>; and * Pay contribution to their employees' Social Security<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.perkeso.gov.my/index.php/en/social-security-protection/employer-employee-eligibility|title=Employer & Employee Eligibility|last=User|first=Super|website=www.perkeso.gov.my|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-16}}</ref>.
==== Online Businesses ==== In 2016, the SSM took legal action against 478 online businesses who fail to register their businesses whether as sole proprietors, partnerships, or private limited companies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/01/26/ssm-unregistered-businesses-cannot-sell-products-online/|title=SSM: Unregistered businesses cannot sell products online - Nation {{!}} The Star Online|website=www.thestar.com.my|access-date=2018-01-16}}</ref> As at May 12 2017, a total of 50,882 online businesses have registered with the SSM since 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.astroawani.com/berita-bisnes/50-882-peniaga-online-berdaftar-dengan-ssm-143421|title=50882 peniaga online berdaftar dengan SSM|website=www.astroawani.com|language=ms|access-date=2018-01-16}}</ref>
===United Kingdom === A sole trader is the simplest type of business structure defined in UK law. It refers to an individual who owns their own business and retains all the profits from it. When starting up, sole traders must complete a straightforward registration with [[HM Revenue and Customs]] as self-employed for tax and National Insurance purposes.<ref>HMRC, [http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/selfemployed/register-selfemp.htm First Steps To Register As Self-Employed]</ref> They are responsible for maintaining the businesses records and submitting an annual Tax return for all income from self-employment and other work.<ref>Business Link, [http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/bdotg/action/detail?itemId=1073789606&type=RESOURCES Legal Structures: The Basics - Sole Trader]</ref>
In Britain, anyone who begins work for themselves is considered by the Government to be a self-employed sole trader, regardless of whether or not they have advised [[HM Revenue and Customs]]. A sole trader can keep all the profits of their business after tax has been paid. They must lodge a self-assessment tax return each year, and pay Income Tax as well as [[National Insurance]]. If revenue is expected to be more than £83,000 a year, they must also register for the [[Value Added Tax (United Kingdom)|Value Added Tax]]. A sole trader can employ staff, but is personally responsible for any losses the business makes.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.gov.uk/business-legal-structures/sole-trader|title = Choose a legal structure for your business|date = 1 April 2015|accessdate = 7 July 2015|website = GOV.UK}}</ref>
==== Advantages ==== Becoming a sole trader is relatively simple compared to other business structures. It can rapidly enable a business to begin trading; the requirements for record keeping are far more straightforward than other business structures. Sole traders make all operational decisions and are solely responsible for raising business finance. They can invest their own capital into the business, or may be able to access business loans and/or overdrafts. Unlike limited companies or partnerships, it is not necessary to share decision making or the profits.<ref>{{cite web|title=Set up as a sole trader|url=https://www.gov.uk/set-up-sole-trader|website=gov.uk|publisher=Crown}}</ref>
==== Disadvantages ==== The simplicity of this structure also has its limitations. Unlike forming a limited company, it lacks the clear cut definition between personal and business income from the perspective of the tax authorities.{{Fact|date=July 2012}} The business owner is personally liable for income tax and National Insurance contributions due for the business profits in each given tax year. They are also personally liable for any debts the business incurs. Business analysts may advise sole traders to form a limited company in order to access greater levels of financing, for example for expansion plans. This can limit their personal liability; business lenders may be more inclined to co-operate with a limited company. It can also be the case that within certain industries it is easier to secure work if presenting potential business partners with a [[Limited company|limited company structure]].
===United States=== In the United States there are no formalities that must be followed to start a sole proprietorship or commence business as a sole proprietor.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Larson|first1=Aaron|title=The Sole Proprietorship|url=https://www.expertlaw.com/library/business/sole_proprietorship.html|website=ExpertLaw|accessdate=26 January 2018|date=7 July 2016}}</ref> However, depending upon the business activity of the sole proprietorship, sole proprietors may require licenses and permits in order to conduct business.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Carter|first1=Christopher|title=What Are the Registration Requirements & Procedures for Sole Proprietorship?|url=http://smallbusiness.chron.com/registration-requirements-procedures-sole-proprietorship-3953.html|website=Chron|publisher=Texas Chronicle|accessdate=26 January 2018}}</ref>
According to the [[Small Business Administration]] (SBA) a sole proprietor and their business are considered as one and the same; therefore, the business is not subjected to separate taxation and regarded as the direct income of the owner. Income, losses and expenses may be listed on a Schedule C, which is then transferred to the personal tax return of the owner.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sole Proprietorships|url=https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/sole-proprietorships|website=IRS|publisher=Internal Revenue Service|accessdate=26 January 2018|date=14 December 2017}}</ref> It is the responsibility of the owner to ensure all due income taxes and self-employment contributions are paid.
A permitted exception to the sole proprietor (single owner) stipulation is made by the [[Internal Revenue Service]] (IRS) permitting the spouse of a sole proprietor to work for the business. They are not classified as partners in the enterprise, or an [[independent contractor]], enabling the business to retain its sole proprietorship status and not be required to submit a partnership income tax return.<ref>{{cite web|title=Husband and Wife Business|url=https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/husband-and-wife-business|website=Internal Revenue Service|publisher=irs.gov|accessdate=8 September 2016}}</ref>
====Foundation and development==== The setting-up process of a sole proprietorship to comply with local laws and regulations, is obtainable from the Small Business Development Center (SBDC), using their locator facility. A sole proprietor must be prepared to devote their time, utilizing business methods towards establishing a sound and appropriate foundation. Doing so may contribute to increased turnover, profits, minimize taxes, and avoid other potential adversities. <ref>{{cite book|last1=Weltman|first1=Barbara|title=J.K. Lasser's Small Business Taxes 2011: Your Complete Guide to a Better|date=2011|publisher=Wiley|isbn=0470939575|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w7ruyHGt6BYC|accessdate=26 January 2018}}</ref>
Sole owners are engaged in many varieties of industry and commerce and a comprehensive list of the primary categories, is found in the [[North American Industry Classification System]] (NAICS). The selection of a business type by a new sole proprietor is in many instances, motivated by appropriate business experience in a particular field, especially those pertaining to enterprises involving the marketing and selling of defined products and services.
A crucial component of a sole proprietorship within a business plan is the provision of an inherent guideline, for actions that require implementing for a business to achieve growth. The business name and products are critical aspects in the founding of a sole proprietorship and once selected, should be protected. In the event of a determined brand name being legalized, information regarding trademark protection is available from the U.S. Patent and [[Trademark]] Office.
====Finances==== For the sole proprietor there are a variety of options in obtaining financial support for their business, including loan facilities available from the U.S. [[Small Business Administration]]. The loans are not originated by the SBA, but the administration does guarantee loans made by various independent lending institutions. The primary loan facility for small businesses offered by this agency is the 7(a) loan program, designed for general applications.<ref>{{cite web|title = 7(a) Loan Program|url = https://www.sba.gov/7a-loan-program|website = SBA.gov|accessdate = 11 December 2014}}</ref> Sole proprietors are able to finance legitimate operating expenses; for example, working capital, furniture, leasehold improvements and building renovations.
Many and varied private [[organizations]] and individuals seek opportunities to invest and fund a business that may not qualify for [[Small business financing|traditional financing]] from institutions, such as banks. For the sole proprietor, seeking to take advantage of this facility, there are various factors that must be understood and adhered to regarding the [[loan application]].
The [[Small Business Administration]] (SBA) advises there are traditionally two forms of financing: [[debt]] and [[Equity (finance)|equity]]. For any [[small business owner]] seeking funding, they must consider the [[debt-to-equity ratio]] of their enterprise.<ref>{{cite web|title=The SBA Loan Guarantee Program|url=https://www.sba.gov/sites/default/files/SDOLoanFactSheet_Oct_2011.pdf|website=Small Business Administration|accessdate=26 January 2018|date=October 2011}}</ref> This means the inter-action between the sum of dollars borrowed and the financial dollars invested in the business. The mathematics are simple; greater the finance invested by sole proprietors in their business; easier the obtaining of finance! The SBA statistics show that the majority of [[small enterprises]] favor the use of limited equity financing; for example, friends and relatives.
According to the SBA, there are various private organizations prepared to fund sole proprietor [[business operations]] that do not qualify for traditional financing from banks. These [[private investors]] can provide loans, credit lines, leasing facilities for equipment, or other forms of capital, to sole proprietorship that have exhausted alternative financial resources. It is also possible for these owners to obtain financing by way of [[business partners]] or others, with cash to invest. Financial partners are frequently “silent” and although they do not participate in any business related decisions, they generally receive a percentage of the profits, generated by the business.
To assist sole proprietors, there are business grants available from the Federal Government or private organizations, providing certain criteria are met. To qualify for Federal grants,<ref>{{cite web|title = Sole Proprietorship Loan Programs|url = http://www.sba.gov/category/navigation-structure/loans-grants/small-business-loans/sba-loan-programs|website = SBA.gov|accessdate = 11 December 2014}}</ref> small businesses must comply with determined business size and income standards. For consideration regarding various grant opportunities, sole proprietors may apply for a grant in their capacity as an individual. [[Local governments]] and state economic development agencies, frequently make [[grants]] available, for businesses that stimulate their [[local economies]].
For any sole proprietor applying for a loan, before starting the loan procedure, it is essential their personal and business credit history is in order and up-to-date. A personal credit report should be obtained from a credit bureau; for example, Trans-Union, [[Equifax]] or [[Experian]]. This action should be initiated by a business owner well before starting the borrowing process.
The [[Small Business Administration]] specifies that all credit reports received from any source should be carefully reviewed to ensure that all relevant [[personal information]] is correct. Other content in the report should also be examined particularly that related to the past credit obtained, from sources such as, credit cards, [[mortgages]], student loans, as well as details pertaining to how the credit was repaid.
===Other countries === An exact translation of "sole proprietorship" is unusual, because the focus of the concept can change. An example is the Brazilian concept of "sole business" that was split into two main kinds of [[Freelancer|formal freelancer]]: *'''sole professional''': with [[Academic certificate#Higher level academic certificates|higher level academic certificate]] and regulations for formal control of autonomous exercise (ex. sole doctor's office). *'''sole entrepreneur''': typical "little entrepreneurs", as sole craftsman, autonomous taxi driver, and many others, that can be formal. An [[Informal sector|informal]] freelancer, through a simple process, can be formalized as ''sole microentrepreneur''
[[German tax system|German]] and [[Law of Austria|Austrian]] tax laws also differentiate between sole professionals and other sole proprietors.

'''Space jurisdiction''', a field addressing what countries can enforce various [[law]]s in [[outer space|space]], has become more important as the private sector enters the field of [[space tourism]]. Under the [[Outer Space Treaty]] of 1967, while space and celestial bodies cannot be appropriated by nations, objects launched into space and personnel on board them remain under the jurisdiction of the state of registry.
== International treaties == The majority of international treaties currently in existence address only specific aspects of space. No major treaties have been passed that have broad, sweeping jurisdiction in space, and it is largely unclear who would enforce such laws. The treaties currently in existence regarding [[space law]] include the following:
*The [[Outer Space Treaty]] of 1967 *The [[Rescue Agreement]] of 1968. *The [[Space Liability Convention]] of 1972. *The [[Registration Convention]] of 1976.
The [[Moon Treaty]] of 1979 was proposed after the Outer Space Treaty, but failed to be ratified by any major [[Space-faring nations|space-faring nation]] such as those capable of [[Timeline of first orbital launches by country|orbital spaceflight]].<ref name='UNOOSA'>[http://www.unoosa.org/pdf/publications/ST_SPACE_11_Rev2_Add1E.pdf Status of international agreements relating to activities in outer space as at 1 January 2008] United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs, 2008</ref>. If it had been broadly accepted, the result would have been an international regime overseeing extraction of resources from celestial bodies.
== Trade in space == Issues of trade and crime in space have not been debated except with respect to the [[International Space Station]]. Agreements have involved all units in operation including Europe, the United States, Russia, Canada, and Japan. Three basic levels of agreement include:
*[[International Space Station]] [[Intergovernmental Agreement]], an [[international treaty]] signed on Jan. 29, 1998 by the fifteen governments involved in the Space Station project. This governmental-level document provides for teamwork between the involved countries in a peaceful [[Space Station]]. *Four [[Memorandum of Understanding|Memoranda of Understanding]], an agreement between the [[National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] and each co-operating Space Agency: [[European Space Agency]], [[Canadian Space Agency]], [[Russian Federal Space Agency]] ([[Roscosmos]]), and [[Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency]]. The objective of these space agencies-level agreements is to specify the roles and responsibilities of each agency in the design, development, operation and utilization of the Space Station.
== Space marriage == Space marriage is a relatively unexplored but emerging attraction of [[space tourism]] industry in the private sector. As more private companies start to travel into space, the demand for such services as marriage in space may increase.
On August 10, 2003, Russian cosmonaut [[Yuri Malenchenko]] became the first human to marry in space. A provision in [[Texas]] [[marriage]] laws, that says one party does not have to be present so long as the couple presents an [[affidavit]] explaining why one of the two participants in the ceremony can't attend, allowed Malenchenko to marry his bride, [[Ekaterina Dmitriev]], from the [[International Space Station]].
==Other matters of space jurisdiction== With the failure of the Moon Treaty of 1979 (which would have established a principle of the [[common heritage of mankind]] for celestial bodies and required establishing an international regime to supervise use), there is no clear rule regarding the development or use of resources located in space, whether by states or private parties. The United States has asserted a right for U.S. citizens to own space resources they obtain, per the U.S. Commercial Space Launch Competitiveness Act (H.R. 2262) § 51303:<ref>http://www.planetaryresources.com/2015/11/president-obama-signs-bill-recognizing-asteroid-resource-property-rights-into-law/</ref> {{Quote|text= A United States citizen engaged in commercial recovery of an asteroid resource or a space resource under this chapter shall be entitled to any asteroid resource or space resource obtained, including to possess, own, transport, use, and sell the asteroid resource or space resource obtained in accordance with applicable law, including the international obligations of the United States}}
Crimes committed in space, under current law, currently would seem to fall to the same mix of claims of jurisdiction by state of registry, nationality of the perpetrator, and nationality of the victim that govern crimes on the [[high seas]] or in [[Antarctica]].

[[File:Fred Thompson in spin room.jpg|thumb|right|240px|Former U.S. Senator and debate participant [[Fred Thompson]] addresses reporters in the spin room following a [[Republican Party presidential debates, 2008#December 9.2C 2007 - Miami.2C Florida|Republican presidential primary debate]] in 2007.]]
A '''spin room''', also known as '''spin row'''<ref>{{cite web|last=Reaves|first=Jessica|title=As the Spin Room Turns|url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,56609,00.html|work=Time|accessdate=2 October 2012|date=4 October 2000}}</ref> or '''spin alley''',<ref>{{cite news|last=Mathes|first=Michael|title=Spin Alley: getting out the message over debate din|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i-iFl3wU6MNVZvub-ufTpJcw7jig|accessdate=23 October 2012|newspaper=Agence France-Presse|date=23 October 2012}}</ref><ref name="TribCritic">{{cite web|last=Rosenthal|first=Phil|title=Spin room coverage out of control|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2008-09-26/business/0809250750_1_post-debate-spin-operatives|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=2 October 2012|date=26 September 2008}}</ref> is an area in which [[reporter]]s can speak with [[debate]] participants and/or their representatives after a debate. The name refers to the fact that the participants will attempt to "[[spin (public relations)|spin]]" or influence the perception of the debate among the assembled reporters. The benefit for reporters is that they quickly get in-person interviews with debaters or their representatives, complete with audio, video and photos. For a [[United States presidential election debates|U.S. presidential debate]], the number of reporters in the spin room can number into the thousands.<ref name="TwitterSpin">{{cite web|last=Calderone|first=Michael|title=For 2012 Presidential Debates, Campaigns Speed Up The Spin|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/10/01/2012-presidential-debates-spin-room_n_1929185.html|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=2 October 2012|date=1 October 2012}}</ref>
==History== The earliest known spin room was set up by the [[political campaign|campaign]] of U.S. president [[Ronald Reagan]] in 1984. In a hotel banquet room, campaign officials spoke on the record with [[talking point]]s playing up their own candidate's debate performance and minimizing opponent [[Walter Mondale]]'s success, despite many observers believing Mondale had just won. This operation was dubbed the "spin patrol."<ref>{{cite news|last=Santini|first=Maureen|title='Spin patrol' spins out|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=toNGAAAAIBAJ&pg=2229,1288893|accessdate=18 October 2012|newspaper=The Evening News|date=13 October 1984|agency=The Associated Press|location=Newburgh-Beacon, New York}}</ref>
==Operation== A spin room may also be active before a debate.<ref>{{cite web|last=Miller|first=Zeke|title=Before The Spin Room, Campaigns Pre-Wash The Press|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/zekejmiller/before-the-spin-room-campaigns-pre-wash-the-press|work=BuzzFeed|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=17 October 2012}}</ref> A common form of pre-debate spin is for each side to try to raise expectations for the opposing debater and lower expectations for their own team, a pursuit known as playing the [[expectations game]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=Leigh Ann|title=What's behind the debate expectations game?|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-250_162-57529085/whats-behind-the-debate-expectations-game/|work=CBS News|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=10 October 2012}}</ref>
==Criticism== Some observers have criticized the overt nature of the [[media manipulation]] in spin rooms, and the media's willing participation in it.<ref name="TribCritic"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Rosen|first=Jay|title=Raze Spin Alley, That Strange Creation of the Press|url=http://archive.pressthink.org/2003/11/22/spin_alley.html|work=PressThink|accessdate=23 October 2012|date=22 November 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Lanson|first=Jerry|title=The spin room - oily engine of the political meat grinder|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2003/1212/p11s01-coop.htm|work=The Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=12 December 2003}}</ref> Defenders have said reporters know it's scripted and aren't persuaded by the spin, but rather, they use the talking points to analyze candidates' strategies.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hardman|first1=Isabel|title=A (partial) defence of the spin room|url=http://blogs.spectator.co.uk/coffeehouse/2015/04/a-partial-defence-of-the-spin-room/|website=The Spectator|accessdate=6 August 2015|date=30 April 2015}}</ref> Spin rooms can occasionally include moments of candor, such as when presidential candidate [[Rick Perry]] admitted that he had "stepped in it" during a debate response that became known as his [[Rick Perry presidential campaign, 2012#November 2011: "Oops" moment and continued struggles|"oops" moment]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Perry in spin room explains flub: "I stepped in it" (with video)|url=http://blogs.star-telegram.com/politex/2011/11/perry-in-spin-room-explains-flub-i-stepped-in-it-with-video.html|website=PoliTex|accessdate=6 August 2015|date=9 November 2011}}</ref>
Spin rooms have also been portrayed as outdated in an era of instant online reaction from all quarters before a debate is even over.<ref name="TwitterSpin"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Gaudin|first=Sharon|title=Twitter becomes new debate spin room|url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9232060/Twitter_becomes_new_debate_spin_room|work=Computer World|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=4 October 2012}}</ref> [[Focus group]]s and instant post-debate "snap [[opinion poll|polls]]" attempt to provide a more scientific method than spin rooms in determining who has won a debate.<ref>{{cite web|title=US presidential debate: Early polls give Barack Obama slender victory|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/uselection2008/presidentialdebates/3092194/US-presidential-debate-Early-polls-give-Barack-Obama-slender-victory.html|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=15 October 2015|date=27 September 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Clegg Beats Brown, Cameron in U.K. TV Debate, Polls Show|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-04-15/clegg-wins-top-mark-in-u-k-debate-polls-as-brown-cameron-stay-deadlocked.html|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=9 November 2012|date=16 April 2010}}</ref>

{{Italic title}} [[File:Texas Tech Administrative Law Journal seal.png|thumb|right|Texas Tech Administrative Law Journal logo]] The '''''Texas Tech Administrative Law Journal''''' is a student-run [[law review]] discussing developments and issues in [[Texas]] [[administrative law]]. It was established in 2000 and is sponsored by the Administrative and Public Law Section of the [[State Bar of Texas]]. Its staff consists of second and third year law students from the [[Texas Tech University School of Law]].
The journal compiles articles in two annual books. It may be accessed via [[Westlaw]], [[LexisNexis]], and [[HeinOnline]].
==Selection== The journal selects new members based upon their performance in a write-on competition that is open to first-year students and chooses twenty individuals.
==History== The journal was founded in 2000 and is the law school's second-oldest journal. The journal will cease publication after the 2018-2019 school year.
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.administrativelawjournal.org}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071201160858/http://adminlaw.org/index.htm Texas Administrative and Public Law Section Homepage]
